4.1.6.9  Communicating Results/Follow-up

The incident investigation report must be reviewed with employees, including contract employees, whose job tasks are relevant to the incident findings.  The Team Leader may arrange for one or more review sessions with affected employees. The purpose of the meeting is to explain the outcome of the investigation.  The Team, as part of its work, may have developed a list of affected individuals (by name or job description) who should be involved in the review process. The Team may consider incident circumstances in determining who the affected employees are. Boskovich Farms, Inc. will ensure that all appropriate affected personnel are in attendance at a review session. Minutes of review sessions will include the names of all individuals in attendance as well as any major issues that were raised during the review.

The Team Leader may issue periodic Team status reports until the Incident Investigation Report Form is completed. Thereafter, the Team Leader is responsible for issuing periodic status reports until all recommended corrective and preventive actions are fully implemented or

The following initial information should be added to the checklist during the preliminary assessment of the situation:
 
Assessment of pre-incident site condition (condition of diked areas, surface runoff, ground condition and containment capability and ambient environmental conditions);

rs issued; and

The ERC will assess possible hazards both direct and indirect to human health and/or the environment or property both inside and outside of the plant. After this information is received, a decision is made whether or not to enact the provisions of this emergency response plan and to set up an Emergency Operations Center (EOC).  If the EOC is activated, the ERC will report immediately to the EOC to take charge of the emergency.

5.9  		ESTABLISHMENT OF OBJECTIVES AND PRIORITIES FOR RESPONSE

5.9.1 	Establish Emergency Operations Center (EOC)
 
This facility has established an emergency operations center (EOC) to serve as the command center from which all emergency response activities are coordinated. The EOC is located in the operations office. The back-up EOC is located in the corporate office. The back-up EOC will be used in the event that the primary EOC is unusable for any reason.

The EOC is activated at the discretion of the ERC or his alternate. The EOC should be activated for all emergencies meeting any of the following criteria:
 
Extended, on-going release of a hazardous material;
Release of a hazardous material resulting in injuries to facility personnel;
Release of a hazardous material causing, or potentially causing, an off-site impact;
Incidents resulting in the need to coordinate the activities of local, state or federal response agencies or an outside contractor; and,
		Incidents where the response activities are expected to continue beyond a 2 - 3 hour time period.
 

The ERC will activate the EOC after making an initial assessment of the incident. If the EOC is activated, the emergency response team members are instructed by the emergency telephone operator or using the intercom system to gather at that location. The ERC will direct all emergency response activities from the EOC.

4.1.2  	Operating Procedures

 
Clearly written standard operating procedures ensure that both experienced and inexperienced employees are given clear, consistent instructions for safely conducting activities involving the covered process.  Boskovich Farms, Inc. has written operating procedures satisfying the requirements of Section 2755.3 of the CalARP regulation.  

Boskovich Farms, Inc. is using operating procedures developed for the HydroVac™ by Western Pre-cooling Systems.  We have prepared SOPs for the Main Refrigeration Unit.  All operating procedures are reviewed and authorized by the Lead Operator and Plant Manager before implementation.  These procedures address various modes of operation such as initial startup, normal operations, temporary operations, emergency shutdown, emergency operations, normal shutdown and startup after a turnaround.  The information is regularly reviewed and is readily accessible to operators involved in the processes.

Date of Most Recent Review/Revision of Safety Information: August 23, 2012

4.1.3   Training

Boskovich Farms, Inc. is developing a training program to ensure that employees who are operating processes are competent in the operating procedures associated with these processes.  Boskovich Farms, Inc.  believes that employees who clearly understand how to safely operate the ammonia refrigeration systems can significantly decrease the number and severity of incidents, while increasing efficiency.  

Type of Training and Competency Training

The training program satisfies the requirements of Section 2755.4 of the Cal ARP regulation that is comprised of the following:

Initial employee classroom training.
Certification for employees operating the process. 
Refresher training every three years, or more often as needed.
Training in updated or new procedures.

Training logs and records can be found at the end of this section.

4.1.4   Maintenance

Boskovich Farms, Inc. carries out do

cumented maintenance checks on process equipment.  Process equipment examined by these checks includes among others, pressure vessels, storage tanks, piping systems, relief and vent systems, emergency shutdown systems, controls and pumps.  Maintenance operations are carried out by qualified contract personnel with previous training in maintenance practices. Any equipment deficiencies identified by the maintenance checks are corrected in a safe and timely manner.

4.1.5   Compliance Audits

 
Boskovich Farms, Inc. conducts audits on a semi annual basis to determine whether the provisions set out under the CalARP regulations are being implemented.  Corrective actions required as a result of the audits are undertaken in a safe and prompt manner.

A Compliance Audit performed by RAMCO, as a consulting expert, is carried out at least every two to three years.  Any corrective actions determined as a result are undertaken in a safe and prompt manner.  

Date of Most Recent Compliance Audit: August 23, 2012

4.1.6   Incident Investigation

Boskovich Farms, Inc. promptly investigates any incident that has resulted in, or could reasonably result in a catastrophic release of a regulated substance.  An investigation will be initiated no later than 48 hours following the incident. These investigations are undertaken to identify the situation leading to the incident as well as any corrective actions to prevent the release from reoccurring.  An investigation team will be established and a report prepared, as detailed below. All reports are retained for a minimum of five years.

No Recent Incident Investigation has been done.

4.1.6.1  Purpose

The purpose of investigating serious incidents and near-misses is to understand what happened (or could have happened) and then to prevent any recurrence of similar incidents, thereby improving the safety of the process.

4.1.6.2   Scope

An incident investigation will be performed any time there is an incident which r

esults in, or which could reasonably have resulted in (near-miss), a catastrophic release of ammonia. A catastrophic release can be defined as a major uncontrolled emission, fire, or explosion involving ammonia that presents serious danger to employees, including contract employees working on-site.

The following is a list of the criteria that will be used to determine whether an incident investigation should be performed. (Note: In the case of a near-miss, judgment must be made as to the potential results as opposed to the actual results.)
	¿ Quantity of Ammonia Released 
	¿ Property Damage 
	¿ Fire or Explosion 
	¿ Injuries or Deaths 

4.1.6.3  Procedures

Boskovich Farms, Inc. initiates incident investigations as promptly as possible, but at least within 48 hours, and will establish a team including at least one person knowledgeable in the process, a contract employee if the incident involved a contract employer's work, and other personnel with the knowledge and experience to thoroughly investigate and analyze the incident. A report including the date of the incident, the date the investigation began, a description of the incident, factors that contributed to the incident, and any recommendations resulting from the investigation. 

Boskovich Farms, Inc. has established a system to address and resolve the team's findings and recommendations and document the resolutions and corrective actions taken.  In addition, the report will be reviewed with affected personnel, including contract employees, whose job tasks are relevant to the incident findings and will be retained for at least five years.  

The following sections outline the steps and procedures we will take to meet the requirements listed above.

4.1.6.4  Initial Incident Response

	The relative priority of response to a serious incident should be:
	Providing medical and other safety and health assistance to personnel.
	Bringing the incident under control.

The ERC, or his designee, will remain in the EOC throughout the duration of the incident. This will help ensure proper and effective implementation of the emergency response procedures by making the ERC immediately available and reachable to make the necessary decisions. 

The ERC will be equipped with appropriate communications equipment and information necessary for proper implementation of the plan.

5.9.2		Set Immediate Goals and Objectives

The main objective of the initial response by the emergency response team will be to determine the extent of the incident, particularly regarding any possible personnel injuries.  The following provides an approximate order of priority for responding to emergencies:
 
Response to personnel injuries
Stopping leak/discharge
Containment of leak/discharge
Corporate notification
Notification to governmental agencies
Spill clean-up/decontamination
 

Operation of the EOC should allow several of these priorities to occur simultaneously.

5.9.3  	Specify Mitigating Actions

Once the immediate goals and objectives are established, a tactical plan should be developed which specifies the mitigating actions which are needed. The tactical plan should address the following questions:
 
Does the area need to been evacuated?
Do hot and cold zones need to be established in the area?
Does anyone need to be rescued from the area?
Will anyone require medical attention?
What corrective actions should be taken which will contain, control, or stop the emergency conditions?
What company personnel, off-site responders, or government agencies should be contacted?

5.1  	PURPOSE AND SCOPE

This Emergency Response Plan is for the Boskovich Farms, Inc. facility located at 711 Diaz Avenue, Oxnard, California 93030.  This document is to ensure that the facility is properly prepared and equipped to respond to a fire, explosion, or an unplanned or accidental discharge of a hazardous substance. This Emergency Response Plan addresses the actions that will be taken.

This plan was designed specifically to conform to the following Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) regulations:

 
Process Safety Management (PSM) of Highly Hazardous Chemicals Requirements (29 CFR 1910.119)
Employee Emergency Plans and Fire Prevention Plans, 29 CFR 1910.38(a)
Hazardous Waste Operations and Emergency Response, 29 CFR 1910.120(q)
Employee Alarm Systems, 29 CFR 1910.165
Risk Management Programs for Chemical Accidental Release Prevention (40 CFR Part 68)

 
5.2  	STATEMENT OF POLICY

It is the policy of Boskovich Farms, Inc. facility management to implement the requirements of    this Emergency Response Plan by managing and operating the facility in accordance with the OSHA and EPA regulations and general good operating practices. The objective is to minimize the risk of a fire, explosion, or an accidental hazardous material release. Facility management has developed this Emergency Response Plan to ensure a fast and efficient response in the event of an accidental hazardous material release, fire, explosion, or other emergency situation.
Boskovich Farms, Inc. personnel are expected to cooperate with fellow employees and other support personnel as directed by the emergency response management to assure successful resolution of any emerge

ncy.

In addition, there should be no unnecessary delay between the initiation and the completion of an incident investigation.  Boskovich Farms, Inc. will select the members of the Incident Investigation Team (hereafter referred to as the Team). The exact membership of the Team will be dependent upon severity, complexity, and circumstances surrounding the incident. 

A multi-disciplinary team is required to perform the incident investigation.  The team must consist of at least one person knowledgeable in the process involved, including a contract employee if the incident involved the work of the contractor, and other persons with appropriate knowledge and experience to thoroughly investigate and analyze the incident.

SECTION 1

EXECUTIVE SUMMARY 

Boskovich Farms, Inc. is strongly committed to employee, public and environmental safety.  This commitment is demonstrated by our comprehensive accidental release prevention program that covers such areas as design, installation, operating procedures, maintenance, and employee training associated with the processes at our facility.  It is our policy to implement appropriate controls to prevent possible releases of regulated substances.  This program has been prepared pursuant to Part 68 of Title 40 of the Code of Federal Regulations.

This RMP is prepared for the Boskovich Farms, Inc. facility located at 711 Diaz Avenue, Oxnard, California.  The facility is a produce preparation, storage, and distribution facility which operates various ammonia refrigeration systems to cool vegetable or fruit as food produce prior to distribution.  Boskovich Farms, Inc. has approximately 34,600 pounds of anhydrous ammonia refrigerant at the site in several refrigeration systems including portable HydroVac units, the Hydrocooler, two ice machines, and the main refrigeration systems for the cooler buildings.

In July 1993 Boskovich Farms, Inc. prepared a Process Safety Management (PSM) Plan and a Risk Management and Prevention Program (RMPP).  The documents have been updated periodically as required.  These documents are referenced by this RMP because they contain some of the elements required by the EPA for the RMP.

Boskovich Farms, Inc. designates Steven Marquez as the Compliance Officer.  Mr. Marquez has the responsibility to plan, organize, implement, monitor and control the associated risks of our hazardous materials management.  All records associated with the prevention program elements are retained for a minimum of five years unless otherwise specified in the CalARP regulation.

1.1 	ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE

To prevent the accidental release of ammonia, Boskovich Farms, Inc. has developed the following:

Maintenance and inspection procedures to ensure the equipment is properly maintained and functioning properly.
 
Standard operating procedures to ensure that equipment operation minimizes the possibility of an ammonia release.
Employee training so that operators know the proper use of the equipment and that non-operators are aware of the dangers of ammonia and the necessary steps to undertake in the event of an ammonia release.
The facility is secured by fencing around the site and a 24-hour guard to minimize the possibility of a third party damaging equipment or by other means causing a release of the ammonia.

The programs are contained in Binder 1, Risk Management and Prevention Program.  Boskovich Farms, Inc. has prepared an Emergency Response Plan to respond to ammonia releases.  In general the plan includes:
A list of safety equipment available at the facility;
Response procedures for minor leaks;
Response procedures for major leaks;
Agency notification procedures; and
Emergency procedures.

A copy of the Emergency Response Plan (ERP) can be found in Binder 1, RMPP, Section 10.  Further description of the ERP is contained in Section 6 of the RMP.

1.2 	STATIONARY SOURCE AND SUBSTANCE HANDLED

Boskovich Farms, Inc. operates several ammonia cooling systems that cool food produce prior to storage and shipment.  These systems contain an approximate aggregate 34,600 pounds of  anhydrous ammonia.

1.3 	ACCIDENTAL RELEASE SCENARIOS

The Worst Case Scenario is the release of 1,725 pounds of liquid ammonia from one of the refrigeration accumulators (vessel) on one of the ice machines.  This scenario is considered very improbable and would result in offsite impacts with a calculated Toxic Endpoint of 0.6 mile.  The Alternate Scenario considers a leaking valve. 2.1.1 	Chemical Name

Anhydrous Ammonia (Chemical Formula: NHc; CAS No. 7664-41-7)  is commonly used for fertilizer production and an industrial refrigerant.   

Depending on the concentration and duration release and exposure, the health effects of ammonia gas can range from mild to severe irritation to the lining of the nose, throat, eyes, and lungs.  Inhalation of concentrations above 1000 ppm may injure the lungs with potentially fatal results.  

Due to its low odor threshold of 5 ppm, ammonia has very good warning properties.  However odor is not a safe nor recommended detector of ammonia in the work place.  On a time weighted average of exposure, or repeated exposure to low levels, which are either at or below the AIHA specified maximum airborne concentration known as EPRG-1, a release of ammonia may reduce a worker's ability to sense the presence of ammonia.

The level of concern(LOC) as mandated in the CalARP regulations, EPRG-2, maximum airborne ammonia concentration of 200 ppmv. At this acute concentration it is believed that nearly all individuals could be exposed for up to one hour without experiencing or developing irreversible or otherwise serious health effects or symptoms which could impair an individual's ability to take self-protective action.

2.1.4 	Scenario

The stationary ammonia refrigeration systems can be connected to the AAARP plant at the adjacent co-gen plant of Sithe Energies.  This allows Boskovich Farms, Inc. the flexibility to import/export ammonia using the Sithe absorption refrigeration system in lieu of operating their own individual refrigeration system compressors.  The Sithe AAARP plant is not part of this Risk Management Plan as it is covered by Sithe Energies.  However, since there is a large ammonia receiver vessel for the AAARP plant located on Boskovich Farms, Inc. property, this vessel was considered for the Worst Case Scenario (WCS).  

U.S. EPA's RMP*Comp software was used to screen Worst Case Scenarios for the four largest ammonia refrigeration systems on site.  Releases were considered for:

AAARP receiver - 15,755 lbs total capac

ity.
West Freezer recirculator vessel - capacity approximately 2,820 lbs.
Fresh Cut receiver vessel - capacity approximately 3,000 lbs.
Ice Plant largest receiver vessel - capacity 1,725 lbs.

AAARP:  This system's entire volume can be contained in a large, low-pressure vertical vessel (7'dia x 11') at the north-east corner of the property.  A 12' x 15' dike has been built around this pressure vessel to contain a potential spill.  Assuming all liquid released from the vessel will pool in this dike, release rate is rather low and the Toxic End Point (TEP) distance is less than 0.3 mile.

West Freezer/Pressure Cooler:  The entire inventory of ammonia in this system could potentially be contained by the new recirculator vessel.  This vessel is located in an equipment room inside the West Freezer building.  Assuming an air-tight building, RMP*Comp adjusts the release rate to 10% of the rate in open air.  For this case the rate would be 172 lbs/min.  This results in a TEP distance of about 0.6 mile.

Fresh Cut:  While the volume of the system is listed as 8,500 lbs., the single largest vessel in the system which is in the engine room can hold about 6,500 lbs.  Assuming the engine room is air-tight,  flow will be 65 lbs/min and the TEP distance is less than 0.4 mile.

Ice Plant:  The ammonia inventory listed for each ice plant is a little more than the receiver can hold, but the entire inventory of 1,725 lbs was use to evaluate this scenario.  A release rate of 190 lbs/min results in a slightly longer TEP than for the West Freezer case, but still about 0.6 mile.

The Ice Plant release scenario was selected as the WCS for the Boskovich Farms, Inc. site.  Total ammonia release would be approximately 1,725 pounds from the liquid receiver vessel (2' dia. x 16' long, volume approximately 50 cu. ft.) on top of the ice machine, in open air. Process Control  By conducting comprehensive reviews to identify hazards associated with our processes, Boskovich Farms, Inc. has been able to plan and take the appropriate action to help secure the safety of our employees, the community, and the environment. 

The first Preliminary Hazard Analysis (PHA) was conducted by a team of qualified individuals, familiar with these systems, using a simplified HAZOP methodology.  The PHA was used to identify the following:
Hazards associated with ammonia and the refrigeration process
Applicable external events (including seismic events) that could lead to a release
Possible equipment failures or human errors that could lead to a release
Safeguards used to prevent or mitigate failures or errors
Steps needed to detect or monitor releases
Recommendations/action items to mitigate the hazard

Implementation of recommendations in response to the hazard review findings are prioritized by the hazard review team based on relative risk.  All approved recommendations to be implemented are tracked and documented to completion.  Implementation of some of the critical action items cannot be done with the system in operation.  However, since plant operation is seasonal, appropriate modifications can all be made during the off season.

The most recent PHA was performed on August 23, 2012.  The seismic assessment was conducted on November 13, 2007.  The hazards identified during this hazard review and seismic assessment are summarized in Tables 5-4 and 5-5 at the end of this section.  The hazard review team developed key action items, which include:
Add a remote shutdown switch for shutdown of the entire refrigeration system.
All PRV and their certification tags older than five years shoul

d be replaced; and the date, location, manufacturer and description of the valve should be entered on the refrigeration equipment maintenance log.
All PRV less than five years old should be inspected for leaks, using either the balloon capture or test gauge method, every six months or less.  Certification of the PRV leak test should be indicated no the affixed tag and the refrigeration equipment maintenance log, and by giving written notice to the inspector at Oxnard CUPA.

The seismic assessment was conducted to determine whether reasonable assurances were in place to prevent an ammonia release during an earthquake, as such release might have off site consequences.  A walkthrough review was conducted in accordance with Guidance for California Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) Program Seismic Assessments (January 2004) by an experienced civil engineer who found that a current seismic assessment was not indicated due to a lack of change to any structural component in the ammonia process equipment.  

The main refrigeration system at Boskovich Farms, Inc. is housed in and around the Machinery Room at the south end of the buildings on the property.  Most of the ammonia is contained in two process vessels: a high pressure receiver located at grade outside the building and the recirculator accumulator vessel located inside the building.

In addition to the process system itself, consideration was also given to adjacent buildings or structures that could impact the process and to utility system that would have to be available following an earthquake.  Structural failure of the Machinery Room building could cause damage to the refrigeration system and might result in an ammonia release.  Loss of any utility systems should not impact the system.
